contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=October 2007}} '''Victoria Mxenge''', (1 January 1942, [[King William's Town]], [[Eastern Cape]] - 1985) was a [[South Africa]]n anti-[[apartheid]] activist. Trained as a [[nurse]] and [[Midwifery|midwife]], she began practising law.<ref name=SAinfo2005-05-20> {{cite news | url = http://www.southafrica.info/ess_info/sa_glance/sustainable/update/vessels170505.htm | title = SA's marine protection vessels | publisher = [[SAinfo]] | date = 2005-05-20 | accessdate = 2011-12-04 | quote = Victoria Mxenge and her husband Griffiths, both lawyers aligned to the ANC, were killed in Umlazi township in Durban, also by the apartheid government, in the 1980s. | page = | author = }} [http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.southafrica.info%2Fess_info%2Fsa_glance%2Fsustainable%2Fupdate%2Fvessels170505.htm&date=2011-12-04 mirror] </ref> She became more politically active after her husband [[Griffiths Mxenge|Griffiths]], who had been banned earlier and detained by the [[National Party (South Africa)|National Party]] government, was murdered by the Apartheid government agents led by [[Dirk Coetzee]] in [[Umlazi]] township south of Durban. He had multiple stab wounds and his body was found near the soccer field in Umlazi. A prominent member of the [[United Democratic Front (South Africa)|United Democratic Front]] and the [[Natal Organisation of Women]], she was part of the defence team for the UDF and [[Natal Indian Congress]] during the [[Pietermaritzburg]] Treason Trial. She was assassinated shortly before the trial. Her funeral was attended by over 10,000 people, and letters of condolence were received from [[Nelson Mandela]] and [[Oliver Tambo]] amongst others. Her murderers appeared before the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]]. Mxenge is one of four political activists honoured in [[Johnny Clegg (musician)|Johnny Clegg]]'s song ''Asimbonanga (Mandela)''. In October 2005 the South African Ministry of the Environment launched the third and last [[Lillian Ngoyi class]] environmental patrol vessels named [[Victoria Mxenge (patrol vessel)|''Victoria Mxenge'']] in her honor.<ref name=SAinfo2005-05-20/> ==References== <references/> ==External links== * [http://www.sahistory.org.za/pages/people/bios/mxenge-v.htm South African History article] * [http://www.ru.ac.za/victoriamxengehouse/victoriamxenge/ Rhodes University Biography] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Mxenge, Victoria | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1 January 1942 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1985 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mxenge, Victoria}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:People from King William's Town]] [[Category:Xhosa people]] [[Category:South African nurses]] [[Category:South African activists]] [[Category:Anti-apartheid activists]] [[Category:Assassinated South African people]] [[Category:People murdered in South Africa]] [[Category:Murdered lawyers]] [[Category:South African midwives]] {{SouthAfrica-activist-stub}} {{AntiApartheid-activist-stub}}
